Award.AwardTitle: CCSS: Simultaneous Sparse Coding for Energy Efficient Sensing: from Low-illumination to Super-Clarity Imaging

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a hierarchical representation based on simultaneous sparse coding and explore its potential applications in energy-efficient sensing. The newly constructed hierarchical representation is expected to offer powerful prior models suitable for Bayesian reconstruction of images from noisy or incomplete samples. Two novel applications related to energy-efficient sensing will be studied: low-illumination imaging and super-clarity imaging where the proposed computational approach can help strike a better tradeoff between the cost (energy) and the quality of acquired images.

The intellectual merit of this project includes: 1) hierarchical extension of simultaneous sparse coding will require a new theoretical framework operating with the fewest artificial mathematical structures (e.g., not even the definition of a metric is introduced); 2) the two applications of energy-efficient sensing are new frontiers of computational imaging with potential high impact on both industry (e.g., consumer electronics, mobile devices) and scientific community (e.g., super-resolution microscopy, computational astronomy).

With respect to broader impacts, the PI will make special effort to broadly disseminate the research results at a large scale to promote experimentally-reproducible research in sparse representations and computational imaging. This project will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups by promoting geographic and gender diversities within the NSF program. The proposed research is beneficial to the general public by bringing images of higher quality to people's daily lives at a lower cost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have extended the concept of simultaneous sparse coding (SSC) into a hierarchical formulation by combining it with local self-similarity (LSS)-based multiscale image representation. Such extension allows us to exploit the characteristics of self-repeating patterns in an image across different scales. We have also leveraged the theory of SSC into applications of computational imaging and depth sensing under adversary acquisition conditions (e.g., low illumination, far distance). Since SSC supplies a powerful prior for natural images, it can be used to effectively suppress noise interference or restore missing high-frequency components for the purpose of improving the subjective quality of reconstructed/restored images.


In the scenario of low-illumination, we have developed a SSC-based blind image restoration algorithm capable of removing signal-dependent noise from high-ISO images (e.g., photos taken by an iphone in night environments). In our approach, SSC-based image prior and unknown signal-dependent noise level function are recursively estimated under an alternating optimization framework. Our algorithm has been shown capable of more effectively suppressing undesirable noise than commercial software such as Neat Image. Other applications of the developed blind image denoising algorithm include enhancement of microscopic images, ultrasound images and thermal imagery.


In the scenario of super-clarity, we have developed several SSC-based super-resolution algorithms for photographic images, hyperspectral imagery as well as depth maps. Super-resolution (SR) of photographic images is often known as digital zoom; our study has led an improved hybrid approach that can refine the SSC model parameters by a small number of training images. SR of hyperspectral imagery is more widely known as pan-sharpening; our work has further advanced the state-of-the-art in pan-sharpening. Additionally, we have shown how to improve the spatial resolution of depth maps from the associated color image, which has been called color-guided depth SR. Color-guided depth SR has wide applications in the real world (e.g., Kinect sensors).  


Last but not the last, we have gone beyond the original scope of the proposed research and explored the potential of deep neural networks (deep learning) as an alternative solution to model-based SSC. Our learning-based approaches towards blind image restoration of color-guided depth SR  have shown highly encouraging experimental results (at least comparable to the previous model-based). Learning-based approaches are particularly promising for large zoom ratios (e.g., 8 and 16) where model-based approaches often do not work any more.
